title: Why can't we make paper from some sort of synthetic cellulose fiber instead of needing cellulose from trees? - Quora

response.answer_text: We don’t have to make paper from tree pulp. Three other plants used to make paper come immediately to mind. Bamboo and hemp both make nice paper products in addition to incredibly soft durable clothing. Papyrus has also been used for paper and clothing for millennia. By it’s very name, synthetic, implies an artificial substitution. Synthetic fibers, a petroleum derivative, have been in widespread use since first invented in the 1880’s. A synthetic cellulose fiber is a blend of wood and petroleum products. Most paper manufacturing involves the use of chemicals to break down or create the fibers. Some methods are more environmentally friendly than others. Synthetic Fibers Synthetic fibers for reinforced speciality paper. PP + PE fibers Patent US2477000 - Synthetic fiber paper Growing the Future of Bamboo Products Hemp 101 Cyperus papyrus Synthetic fiber - Wikipedia Hemphasis.net ~ Hemp Paper vs Tree Pulp Paper

Synthetic paper is already a real thing. It is water resistant and good for applications where you need that. It also makes for good lithograph prints (arguably). Pulp from trees is readily abundant and a renewable resource. When you cut down a tree, you don’t just leave an empty space. You plant a new one. By FSC standards, you plant 3 new trees. After you’re done with that paper, you can throw it out, and it will naturally break down faster than most household waste. Conversely, synthetic paper, which is made from petroleum, will not break down for a very long time. Which do you think is better for the environment?
